p: The results ( Table 5) showed that all essential oil samples were able to reduce the stable DPPH radical to yellow diphenylpicrylhydrazine, with the scavenging effects increasing with higher essential oil concentrations ( p-value ˂ 0.05). Leaf essential oil had the highest antioxidant activity (IC 50: 33.12 ± 0.07 µg/mL), followed by trunk bark oil (IC 50: 65.68 ± 0.12 µg/mL) and fruit oil (IC 50: 103,55 ± 0.35 µg/mL). The comparison with the Trolox standard (29.13 ± 0.04 µg/mL) showed that the selected leaf essential oil sample has a high antioxidant activity. This activity could be due to the high contents in β-caryophyllene and thymol of this essential oil, as both of those molecules are already known for their antioxidant properties [ 57]. Those molecules were either present in lower quantities, or absent in the other tested essential oil samples (trunk bark and fruit).
